newsitem.title: USA: Muni board warns dealers of post-election payments.
newsitem.headline: Muni board warns dealers of post-election payments.

text.p: The MSRB on Friday warned municipal bond dealers that contributions they give to help state and local officials with transition and inaugural expenses following Tuesday's elections could trigger the board's "pay-to-play" ban.

"The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board is deeply concerned that a number of dealers are going to be caught by helping with those inauguration and transition expenses," MSRB Chairman Roger Hayes said in a telephone press conference following a quarterly meeting of the panel on Thursday.
"Everbody be sure and do it in accordance with the rule so that nobody is banned" from doing business for the next two years, said Hayes, managing director of municipal finance for NationsBank Corp.
Enacted in April 1994, rule G-37 bars muni dealers that make contributions to issuer clients from doing business for two years with those governments.

In a one-page "election season reminder" in September, the MSRB noteds that the term "contributions" includes "monies given for transition or inaugural expenses and the payment of debt for an election."
In other announcements, Hayes said the 15-member board will focus soon on "concerns about practices in the formation of syndicates and selling groups and the pricing and allocation of bonds."
"We want to be absolutely sure that's done in a way that's understandable to issuers and to other firms in the underwriting," he said.

"And we want to make sure (there is) the broadest and most efficient distribution of bonds to investors throughout the country," he said, noting the board is following up on a survey it did of bond dealers last summer on the issue.
Hayes said the board also will more carefully examine "the whole process of obtaining financing for an issuer client."
"We want to be absolutely sure that the interest of the issuer is paramount," he said.
He said the board will look at the need for "shedding more light on the role of financial advisers" in bond deals, and the "potential for conflicts among the parties."
The board will look at "the compensation arrangements between the various parties and how that might, in effect, create a conflict of interest," he said.
Hayes said the board will look at "how collateral or related transactions to an issuer might need additional light shed on (them), like swaps, derivatives and guaranteed investment contracts (GICs)."
